Instead of persist export here, we can just pass this to make the same way we pass WHAT
This should also ideally still have a user override if possible ðŸ¤”

Hi @neolit123 do you have time to implement @BenTheElder 's feedback? 

I would be happy to help out if help is wanted.

@RobertKielty
i'm no longer seeing /cmd/kubeadm/ test failures...are you still seeing them?
i'd prefer to keep the default timeout of 120s if we can, instead of making the change in this PR.

i had a question for @BenTheElder , but looks like i didn't post it.
would `make -C "${KUBE_ROOT}" test WHAT=k8s.io/kubernetes/cmd/kubeadm/test/cmd KUBE_TIMEOUT=--timeout=240s` just work here?

@@ -1,1 +128,132 @@  # unless the user sets KUBEADM_PATH, assume that "make all..." just built it
  export KUBEADM_PATH="${KUBEADM_PATH:=$(kube::realpath "${KUBE_ROOT}")/_output/local/go/bin/kubeadm}"
  # invoke the tests
  make -C "${KUBE_ROOT}" test \
    WHAT=k8s.io/kubernetes/cmd/kubeadm/test/cmd \

comments.body: Is there something we could run in the `run_exec_credentials_tests` check to confirm that the client cert auth is enabled on the API server?  I am not sure if this is observable from the outside.  ðŸ¤”

Actually I think you can do something like:

`openssl s_client -connect "127.0.0.1:${API_PORT}" -state`

and check to make sure the output contains:

```
Acceptable client certificate CA names
/CN=127.0.0.1
```

Similar approach:

```
$ echo | openssl s_client -connect "127.0.0.1:${API_PORT}" -msg 2>/dev/null | grep CertificateRequest
```

Should output something like:

```
<<< TLS 1.2 Handshake [length 009b], CertificateRequest
```

Indeed, the `openssl s_client` trick is what I used to figure out that the client certificate capabilities of the API server was what triggered the exec credential plugin before. Added as a pre-condition.
Same here, for `run_kube_controller_manager`
comment was added, this may? actually be read
https://cs.k8s.io/?q=CTLRMGR_PID&i=nope&files=&repos=kubernetes/kubernetes
Same here, for `create_node`
comment was added. similarly this may(?) be read https://cs.k8s.io/?q=SUPPORTED_RESOURCES&i=nope&files=&repos=kubernetes/kubernetes

comments.body: Just thinking aloud here: If we had called these request and response instead of spec and status, then we could have had a convention in kubectl that if a thing has request and response, then kubectl should print out the response.
Probably not enough information to generalize that, actually.  Never mind.

I don't know that we want a ton of output on kubectl create by default.  It
will be extremely difficult to take a random list of objects and make a
usable, effective output.  We'd probably want to err on a very succinct
result, and I doubt our ability to do that generically.

On Wed, Aug 3, 2016 at 3:55 PM, David Eads notifications@github.com wrote:

> In hack/make-rules/test-cmd.sh
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/20573#discussion_r73408443
> :
> 
> > @@ -2324,6 +2324,26 @@ **EOF**
> >    kube::test::get_object_assert "nodes 127.0.0.1" "{{.spec.unschedulable}}" '<no value>'
> > 
> > +
> > -  ########################
> > -  # authorization.k8s.io #
> > -  ########################
> >   +
> > -  # check remote authorization endpoint, kubectl doesn't actually display the returned object so this isn't super useful
> > -  # but it proves that works
> 
> Just thinking aloud here: If we had called these request and response
> instead of spec and status, then we could have had a convention in kubectl
> that if a thing has request and response, then kubectl should print out the
> response.
> 
> I think we probably want a "show me what came back" flag on kubectl create
> so that users can see how their object was defaulted.
> 
> @fabianofranz https://github.com/fabianofranz Want to try to make such
> a thing?
> 
> â€”

> .

> I don't know that we want a ton of output on kubectl create by default.  It
> will be extremely difficult to take a random list of objects and make a
> usable, effective output.  We'd probably want to err on a very succinct
> result, and I doubt our ability to do that generically.

I'd keep the flag off by default, but if you request something like `-o yaml`, I think you expect to see your output, not your input.
